column16: description
column17: comments

column16: The user-defined name for the sample.
column17: The sample_ID should represent the identifier assigned to the sample at time of collection, for which all the descriptive information applies. If the original sample_ID is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: An alternative sample_ID assigned to the sample by another organization.
column17:
"Alternative identifiers assigned to the sample should be tracked along with original IDs to establish chain of custody. Alternative sample IDs should be provided in the in a prescribed format which consists of the ID followed by square brackets (no space in between the ID and bracket) containing the short form of ID provider’s agency name i.e. ID[short organization code]. Agency short forms include the following:
Public Health Agency of Canada: PHAC
Canadian Food Inspection Agency: CFIA
Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada: AAFC
Fisheries and Oceans Canada: DFO
Environment and Climate Change Canada: ECCC
Health Canada: HC 
Multiple identifiers can be provided and separated by semi-colons. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value."

column16: The name of the agency, organization or institution with which the sample collector is affiliated.
column17: Provide the name of the agency, organization or institution that collected the sample in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The specific laboratory affiliation of the sample collector.
column17: Provide the name of the specific laboratory that collected the sample (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name of the project/initiative/program for which the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the name of the project and/or the project ID here. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name of the study design for a surveillance project.
column17: Provide the name of the sample plan used for sample collection. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.
column18: National Microbiological Baseline Study in Broiler Chicken

column16: The identifier of the study design for a surveillance project.
column17: Provide the identifier of the sample plan used for sample collection. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name or job title of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sample.
column17: Provide the name of an individual or their job title. As personnel turnover may render the contact's name obsolete, it is more preferable to provide a job title for ensuring accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sample.
column17: Provide the email associated with the listed contact. As personnel turnover may render an individual's email obsolete, it is more preferable to provide an address for a position or lab, to ensure accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The reason that the sample was collected.
column17: The reason a sample was collected may provide information about potential biases in sampling strategy. Provide the purpose of sampling from the picklist in the template. Most likely, the sample was collected for diagnostic testing. The reason why a sample was originally collected may differ from the reason why it was selected for sequencing, which should be indicated in the "purpose of sequencing" field.

column16: The experimental activities or variables that affected the sample collected.
column17: If there was experimental activity that would affect the sample prior to collection (this is different than sample processing), provide the experimental activities by selecting one or more values from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The details of the experimental activities or variables that affected the sample collected.
column17: Briefly describe the experimental details using free text.
column18: Chicken feed containing X amount of novobiocin was fed to chickens for 72 hours prior to collection of litter.

column16: The name of the overarching experimental methodology that was used to process the biomaterial.
column17: Provide the name of the methodology used in your study. If available, provide a link to the protocol.

column16: The type of role that the sample represents in the experiment.
column17: Samples can play different types of roles in experiments. A sample under study in one experiment may act as a control or be a replicate of another sample in another experiment. This field is used to distinguish samples under study from controls, replicates, etc.  If the sample acted as an experimental control or a replicate, select a role type from the picklist. If the sample was not a control, leave blank or select "Not Applicable".

column16: The processing applied to samples post-collection, prior to further testing, characterization, or isolation procedures.
column17: Provide the sample processing information by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The details of the processing applied to the sample during or after receiving the sample.
column17: Briefly describe the processes applied to the sample.
column18: 25 samples were pooled and further prepared as a single sample during library prep.

column16: The process used to extract genomic material from a sample.
column17: Briefly describe the extraction method used.
column18: Direct wastewater RNA capture and purification via the "Sewage, Salt, Silica and Salmonella (4S)" method v4 found at https://www.protocols.io/view/v-4-direct-wastewater-rna-capture-and-purification-36wgq581ygk5/v4

column16: The kit used to extract genomic material from a sample
column17: Provide the name of the genomic extraction kit used.

column16: The country of origin of the sample.
column17: Provide the name of the country where the sample was collected. Use the controlled vocabulary provided in the template pick list.  If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, provide a null value.

column16: The state/province/territory of origin of the sample.
column17: Provide the name of the province/state/region where the sample was collected.  If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, provide a null value.

column16: The name of a specific geographical location e.g. Credit River (rather than river).
column17: Provide the name of the specific geographical site using a specific noun (a word that names a certain place, thing).

column16: The country of origin of a food product.
column17: If a food product was sampled and the food product was manufactured outside of Canada, provide the name of the country where the food product originated by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The country of origin of the host.
column17: If a sample is from a human or animal host that originated from outside of Canada, provide the the name of the country where the host originated by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The latitude coordinates of the geographical location of sample collection.
column17: If known, provide the degrees latitude.  Do NOT simply provide latitude of the institution if this is not where the sample was collected, nor the centre of the city/region where the sample was collected as this falsely implicates an existing geographical location and creates data inaccuracies. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The longitude coordinates of the geographical location of sample collection.
column17: If known, provide the degrees longitude.  Do NOT simply provide longitude of the institution if this is not where the sample was collected, nor the centre of the city/region where the sample was collected as this falsely implicates an existing geographical location and creates data inaccuracies. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The date on which the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the date according to the ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY".

column16: The precision to which the "sample collection date" was provided.
column17: Provide the precision of granularity to the "day", "month", or "year" for the date provided in the "sample collection date" field. The "sample collection date" will be truncated to the precision specified upon export; "day" for "YYYY-MM-DD", "month" for "YYYY-MM", or "year" for "YYYY".

column16: The date on which sample collection ended for a continuous sample.
column17: Provide the date that sample collection ended in ISO 8601 format i.e. YYYY-MM-DD

column16: The date on which the sample was processed.
column17: Provide the sample processed date in ISO 8601 format, i.e. "YYYY-MM-DD". The sample may be collected and processed (e.g. filtered, extraction) on the same day, or on different dates.

column16: The time at which sample collection began.
column17: Provide this time in ISO 8601 24hr format, in your local time.

column16: The time at which sample collection ended.
column17: Provide this time in ISO 8601 24hr format, in your local time.

column16: The descriptive time of day during which the sample was collected.
column17: If known, select a value from the pick list. The time of sample processing matters especially for grab samples, as fecal concentration in wastewater fluctuates over the course of the day.

column16: The amount of time over which the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the numerical value of time.

column16: The units of the time duration measurement of sample collection.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: The date on which the sample was received.
column17: Provide the date according to the ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY".

column16: The original sample description provided by the sample collector.
column17: Provide the sample description provided by the original sample collector. The original description is useful as it may provide further details, or can be used to clarify higher level classifications.

column16: An environmental location may describe a site in the natural or built environment e.g. hospital, wet market, bat cave.
column17: If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the environmental site from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: A substance obtained from the natural or man-made environment e.g. soil, water, sewage, door handle, bed handrail, face mask.
column17: If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the environmental material from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: The material constituents that comprise an environmental material e.g. lead, plastic, paper.
column17: If applicable, describe the material constituents for the environmental material. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: The type of animal or plant population inhabiting an area.
column17: This field should be used when a sample is taken from an environmental location inhabited by many individuals of a specific type, rather than describing a sample taken from one particular host. If applicable, provide the standardized term and ontology ID for the animal or plant population name. The standardized term can be sourced from this look-up service: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/genepio. If not applicable, leave blank.

column16: A substance obtained from an anatomical part of an organism e.g. tissue, blood.
column17: An anatomical material is a substance taken from the body. If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the anatomical material from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: A substance excreted/secreted from an organism e.g. feces, urine, sweat.
column17: A body product is a substance produced by the body but meant to be excreted/secreted (i.e. not part of the body). If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the body product from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: An anatomical part of an organism e.g. oropharynx.
column17: An anatomical part is a structure or location in the body. If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the anatomical material from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: A 3D region in space without well-defined compartmental boundaries; for example, the dorsal region of an ectoderm.
column17: This field captures more granular spatial information on a host anatomical part e.g. dorso-lateral region vs back. Select a term from the picklist.

column16: A material consumed and digested for nutritional value or enjoyment.
column17: This field includes animal feed. If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the anatomical material from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.
column18: Feather meal [FOODON:00003927]; Bone meal [ENVO:02000054]; Chicken breast [FOODON:00002703]

column16: Any characteristic of the food product pertaining to its state, processing, or implications for consumers.
column17: Provide any characteristics of the food product including whether it has been cooked, processed, preserved, any known information about its state (e.g. raw, ready-to-eat), any known information about its containment (e.g. canned), and any information about a label claim (e.g. organic, fat-free).

column16: The claim made by the label that relates to food processing, allergen information etc.
column17: Provide any characteristic of the food product, as described on the label only.

column16: The animal from which the food product was derived.
column17: Provide the common name of the animal. If not applicable, leave blank. Multiple entries can be provided, separated by a comma.

column16: A production pathway incorporating the processes, material entities (e.g. equipment, animals, locations), and conditions that participate in the generation of a food commodity.
column17: Provide the name of the agricultural production stream from the picklist.

column16: The type of packaging used to contain a food product.
column17: If known, provide information regarding how the food product was packaged.

column16: A date recommended for the use of a product while at peak quality, this date is not a reflection of safety unless used on infant formula.
column17: This date is typically labeled on a food product as "best if used by", best by", "use by", or "freeze by" e.g. 5/24/2020. If the date is known, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: A food product's packaging date as marked by a food manufacturer or retailer.
column17: The packaging date should not be confused with, nor replaced by a Best Before date or other food quality date. If the date is known, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The instrument or container used to collect the sample e.g. swab.
column17: This field includes animal feed. If applicable, select the standardized term and ontology ID for the anatomical material from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: The process used to collect the sample e.g. phlebotomy, necropsy.
column17: If applicable, provide the standardized term and ontology ID for the anatomical material from the picklist provided. Multiple values can be provided, separated by a semi-colon.

column16: The numerical value of the volume measurement of the sample collected.
column17: Provide the numerical value of volume.

column16: The units of the volume measurement of the sample collected.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: The status of the residual sample (whether any sample remains after its original use).
column17: Residual samples are samples that remain after the sample material was used for its original purpose. Select a residual sample status from the picklist. If sample still exists, select "Residual sample remaining (some sample left)".

column16: A specification of the way that a specimen is or was stored.
column17: Provide a description of how the sample was stored.

column16: The material or matrix in which a sample is stored.
column17: Provide a description of the medium in which the sample was stored.

column16: The numerical value of the time measurement during which a sample is in storage.
column17: Provide the numerical value of time.

column16: The units of a measured sample storage duration.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: The numerical value of the time measurement during which the extracted nucleic acid is in storage.
column17: Provide the numerical value of time.

column16: The units of a measured extracted nucleic acid storage duration.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: The type of data that is available, that may or may not require permission to access.
column17: This field provides information about additional data types that are available that may provide context for interpretation of the sequence data. Provide a term from the picklist for additional data types that are available. Additional data types may require special permission to access. Contact the data provider for more information.

column16: Detailed information regarding other available data types.
column17: Use this field to provide free text details describing other available data types that may provide context for interpreting genomic sequence data.
column18: Pooled metagenomes containing extended spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) bacteria

column16: The depth of some water.
column17: Provide the numerical depth only  of water only (without units).

column16: The units of measurement for water depth.
column17: Provide the units of measurement for which the depth was recorded.

column16: The depth of some sediment.
column17: Provide the numerical depth only of the sediment (without units).

column16: The units of measurement for sediment depth.
column17: Provide the units of measurement for which the depth was recorded.

column16: The temperature of some air.
column17: Provide the numerical value for the temperature of the air (without units).

column16: The units of measurement for air temperature.
column17: Provide the units of measurement for which the temperature was recorded.

column16: The temperature of some water.
column17: Provide the numerical value for the temperature of the water (without units).

column16: The units of measurement for water temperature.
column17: Provide the units of measurement for which the temperature was recorded.

column16: The state of the atmosphere at a place and time as regards heat, dryness, sunshine, wind, rain, etc.
column17: Provide the weather conditions at the time of sample collection.

column16: Weather conditions prior to collection that may affect the sample.
column17: Provide the weather conditions prior to sample collection.

column16: The amount of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
column17: Provide the quantity of precipitation in the area leading up to the time of sample collection.

column16: The units of measurement for the amount of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
column17: Provide the units of precipitation by selecting a value from the pick list.

column16: The process used to measure the amount of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or method used to measure precipitation.
column18: Rain gauge over a 12 hour period prior to sample collection

column16: The commonly used name of the host.
column17: If the sample is directly from a host, either a common or scientific name must be provided (although both can be included, if known).  If known, provide the common name.

column16: The taxonomic, or scientific name of the host.
column17: If the sample is directly from a host, either a common or scientific name must be provided (although both can be included, if known).  If known, select the scientific name from the picklist provided.

column16: The biotype resulting from selection in a particular habitat, e.g. the A. thaliana Ecotype Ler.
column17: Provide the name of the ecotype of the host organism.

column16: A breed is a specific group of domestic animals or plants having homogeneous appearance, homogeneous behavior, and other characteristics that distinguish it from other animals or plants of the same species and that were arrived at through selective breeding.
column17: Provide the name of the breed of the host organism.

column16: The name of the host at a certain stage of food production, which may depend on its age or stage of sexual maturity.
column17: Select the host's food production name from the pick list.

column16: Age of host at the time of sampling, expressed as an age group.
column17: Select the corresponding host age bin from the pick list provided in the template. If not available, provide a null value or leave blank.

column16: The name of the disease experienced by the host.
column17: This field is only required if the Pathogen.cl package was selected. If the host was sick, provide the name of the disease.The standardized term can be sourced from this look-up service: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/doid If the disease is not known, put “missing”.

column16: The laboratory method used to grow, prepare, and/or isolate the microbial isolate.
column17: Provide the name and version number of the microbiological method. The ID of the method is also acceptable if the ID can be linked to the laboratory that created the procedure.

column16: The strain identifier.
column17: If the isolate represents or is derived from, a lab reference strain or strain from a type culture collection, provide the strain identifier.

column16: Taxonomic name of the organism.
column17: Put the genus and species (and subspecies if applicable) of the bacteria, if known. The standardized term can be sourced from this look-up service: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/ncbitaxon. Note: If taxonomic identification was performed using metagenomic approaches, multiple organisms may be included. There is no need to list organisms detected as the result of noise in the data (only a few reads present). Only include organism names that you are confident are present. Also include the taxonomic mapping software and reference database(s) used.

column16: The type of planned process by which an organismal entity is associated with a taxon or taxa.
column17: Provide the type of method used to determine the taxonomic identity of the organism by selecting a value from the pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The details of the process used to determine the taxonomic identification of an organism.
column17: Briefly describe the taxonomic identififcation method details using free text.

column16: The serovar of the organism.
column17: Only include this information if it has been determined by traditional serological methods or a validated in silico prediction tool e.g. SISTR.

column16: The method used to determine the serovar.
column17: If the serovar was determined via traditional serotyping methods, put “Traditional serotyping”. If the serovar was determined via in silico methods, provide the name and version number of the software.

column16: The phagetype of the organism.
column17: Provide if known. If unknown, put “missing”.

column16: The user-specified identifier for the library prepared for sequencing.
column17: Every "library ID" from a single submitter must be unique. It can have any format, but we suggest that you make it concise, unique and consistent within your lab, and as informative as possible.

column16: The name of the agency, organization or institution responsible for sequencing the isolate's genome.
column17: Provide the name of the agency, organization or institution that performed the sequencing in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The specific laboratory affiliation of the responsible for sequencing the isolate's genome.
column17: Provide the name of the specific laboratory that that performed the sequencing in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name or title of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
column17: Provide the name of an individual or their job title. As personnel turnover may render the contact's name obsolete, it is more prefereable to provide a job title for ensuring accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
column17: Provide the email associated with the listed contact. As personnel turnover may render an individual's email obsolete, it is more prefereable to provide an address for a position or lab, to ensure accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The reason that the sample was sequenced.
column17: Provide the reason for sequencing by selecting a value from the following pick list: Diagnostic testing, Surveillance, Monitoring, Clinical trial, Field experiment, Environmental testing. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The date the sample was sequenced.
column17: ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The name of the project/initiative/program for which sequencing was performed.
column17: Provide the name of the project and/or the project ID here. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The platform technology used to perform the sequencing.
column17: Provide the name of the company that created the sequencing instrument by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The model of the sequencing instrument used.
column17: Provide the model sequencing instrument by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The overarching sequencing methodology that was used to determine the sequence of a biomaterial.
column17: Example Guidance: Provide the name of the DNA or RNA sequencing technology used in your study. If unsure refer to the protocol documentation, or provide a null value.

column16: The name of the DNA library preparation kit used to generate the library being sequenced.
column17: Provide the name of the library preparation kit used.

column16: The length of the DNA fragment generated by mechanical shearing or enzymatic digestion for the purposes of library preparation.
column17: Provide the fragment length in base pairs (do not include the units).

column16: The molecular technique used to selectively capture and amplify specific regions of interest from a genome.
column17: Provide the name of the enrichment method

column16: Details that provide additional context to the molecular technique used to selectively capture and amplify specific regions of interest from a genome.
column17: Provide details that are applicable to the method you used. Note: If bait-capture methods were used for enrichment, provide the panel name and version number (or a URL providing that information).
column18: enrichment was done using Twist's respiratory virus research panel: https://www.twistbioscience.com/products/ngs/fixed-panels/respiratory-virus-research-panel

column16: The specifications of the primers (primer sequences, binding positions, fragment size generated etc) used to generate the amplicons to be sequenced.
column17: Provide the name and version of the primer scheme used to generate the amplicons for sequencing.

column16: The length of the amplicon generated by PCR amplification.
column17: Provide the amplicon size expressed in base pairs.

column16: The version number of the flow cell used for generating sequence data.
column17: Flow cells can vary in terms of design, chemistry, capacity, etc. The version of the flow cell used to generate sequence data can affect sequence quantity and quality. Record the version of the flow cell used to generate sequence data. Do not include "version" or "v" in the version number.

column16: The protocol or method used for sequencing.
column17: Provide the name and version of the procedure or protocol used for sequencing. You can also provide a link to a protocol online.

column16: The user-specified filename of the r1 FASTQ file.
column17: Provide the r1 FASTQ filename.

column16: The user-specified filename of the r2 FASTQ file.
column17: Provide the r2 FASTQ filename.

column16: The user-specified filename of the FAST5 file.
column17: Provide the FAST5 filename.

column16: The user-defined filename of the FASTA file.
column17: Provide the FASTA filename.

column16: The name of the method used to assess whether a sequence passed a predetermined quality control threshold.
column17: Providing the name of the method used for quality control is very important for interpreting the rest of the QC information. Method names can be provided as the name of a pipeline or a link to a GitHub repository. Multiple methods should be listed and separated by a semi-colon. Do not include QC tags in other fields if no method name is provided.

column16: The version number of the method used to assess whether a sequence passed a predetermined quality control threshold.
column17: Methods updates can make big differences to their outputs. Provide the version of the method used for quality control. The version can be expressed using whatever convention the developer implements (e.g. date, semantic versioning). If multiple methods were used, record the version numbers in the same order as the method names. Separate the version numbers using a semi-colon.

column16: The determination of a quality control assessment.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided. If a desired value is missing, submit a new term request to the PHA4GE QC Tag GitHub issuetracker using the New Term Request form.

column16: The reason contributing to, or causing, a low quality determination in a quality control assessment.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided. If a desired value is missing, submit a new term request to the PHA4GE QC Tag GitHub issuetracker using the New Term Request form.

column16: The details surrounding a low quality determination in a quality control assessment.
column17: Provide notes or details regarding QC results using free text.
column18: CT value of 39. Low viral load. Low DNA concentration after amplification.

column16: The method used for raw data processing such as removing barcodes, adapter trimming, filtering etc.
column17: Raw data processing can have a significant impact on data quality and how it can be used. Provide the names and version numbers of software used for trimming adaptors, quality filtering, etc (e.g. Trimmomatic v. 0.38, Porechop v. 0.2.3), or a link to a GitHub protocol.

column16: The method used to remove host reads from the pathogen sequence.
column17: Provide the name and version number of the software used to remove host reads.

column16: The name of the software used to assemble a sequence.
column17: Provide the name of the software used to assemble the sequence.
column18: SPAdes Genome Assembler, Canu, wtdbg2, velvet

column16: The version of the software used to assemble a sequence.
column17: Provide the version of the software used to assemble the sequence.

column16: The name of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.
column17: Provide the name of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.

column16: The version of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.
column17: Provide the version of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.

column16: The percentage of the reference genome covered by the sequenced data, to a prescribed depth.
column17: Provide value as a percent.

column16: The average number of reads representing a given nucleotide in the reconstructed sequence.
column17: Provide value as a fold of coverage.

column16: The threshold used as a cut-off for the depth of coverage.
column17: Provide the threshold fold coverage.

column16: The percentage of expected genes identified in the genome being sequenced. Missing genes indicate missing genomic regions (incompleteness) in the data.
column17: Provide the genome completeness as a percent (no need to include units).

column16: The number of total base pairs generated by the sequencing process.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The total number of non-unique reads generated by the sequencing process.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The number of unique reads generated by the sequencing process.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The threshold used as a cut-off for the minimum length of a read after trimming.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The number of contigs (contiguous sequences) in a sequence assembly.
column17: Provide a numerical value.

column16: The percentage of the assembly that consists of ambiguous bases (Ns).
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The number of ambiguous bases (Ns) normalized per 100 kilobasepairs (kbp).
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The length of the shortest read that, together with other reads, represents at least 50% of the nucleotides in a set of sequences.
column17: Provide the N50 value in Mb.

column16: The percent of the total number of reads identified as contamination (not belonging to the target organism) in a sequence dataset.
column17: Provide the percent contamination value (no need to include units).

column16: The length of the genome generated by assembling reads using a scaffold or by reference-based mapping.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The length of the genome defined by the most common nucleotides at each position.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: A persistent, unique identifier of a genome database entry.
column17: Provide the accession number of the reference genome.

column16: The method used to remove duplicated reads in a sequence read dataset.
column17: Provide the deduplication software name followed by the version, or a link to a tool or method.

column16: A description of the overall bioinformatics strategy used.
column17: Further details regarding the methods used to process raw data, and/or generate assemblies, and/or generate consensus sequences can. This information can be provided in an SOP or protocol or pipeline/workflow. Provide the name and version number of the protocol, or a GitHub link to a pipeline or workflow.

column16: The name of the software used to map sequence reads to a reference genome or set of reference genes.
column17: Provide the name of the read mapping software.

column16: The version of the software used to map sequence reads to a reference genome or set of reference genes.
column17: Provide the version number of the read mapping software.

column16: The name of the taxonomic reference database used to identify the organism.
column17: Provide the name of the taxonomic reference database.

column16: The version of the taxonomic reference database used to identify the organism.
column17: Provide the version number of the taxonomic reference database.

column16: The filename of the report containing the results of a taxonomic analysis.
column17: Provide the filename of the report containing the results of the taxonomic analysis.

column16: The date a taxonomic analysis was performed.
column17: Providing the date that an analyis was performed can help provide context for tool and reference database versions. Provide the date that the taxonomic analysis was performed in ISO 8601 format, i.e. "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: A description of the criteria used to map reads to a reference sequence.
column17: Provide a description of the read mapping criteria.

column16: The name of the agency that submitted the sequence to a database.
column17: The name of the agency should be written out in full, (with minor exceptions) and be consistent across multiple submissions. If submitting specimens rather than sequencing data, please put the "National Microbiology Laboratory (NML)".

column16: The name or title of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the submission of the sequence to a repository or database.
column17: Provide the name of an individual or their job title. As personnel turnover may render the contact's name obsolete, it is prefereable to provide a job title for ensuring accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email address of the agency responsible for submission of the sequence.
column17: The email address can represent a specific individual or lab e.g. johnnyblogs@lab.ca, or RespLab@lab.ca

column16: The identifier for a publication.
column17: If the isolate is associated with a published work which can provide additional information, provide the PubMed identifier of the publication. Other types of identifiers (e.g. DOI) are also acceptable.

column16: The attribute package used to structure metadata in an INSDC BioSample.
column17: If the sample is from a specific human or animal, put “Pathogen.cl”. If the sample is from an environmental sample including food, feed, production facility, farm, water source, manure etc, put “Pathogen.env”.

column16: The INSDC accession number of the BioProject(s) to which the BioSample belongs.
column17: Required if submission is linked to a BioProject. BioProjects are an organizing tool that links together raw sequence data, assemblies, and their associated metadata. A valid BioProject accession has prefix PRJN, PRJE or PRJD, e.g., PRJNA12345 and is created once at the beginning of a new sequencing project. Your laboratory can have one or many BioProjects.

column16: The identifier assigned to a BioSample in INSDC archives.
column17: Store the accession returned from the BioSample submission. NCBI BioSamples will have the prefix SAMN, whileEMBL- EBI BioSamples will have the prefix SAMEA.

column16: The Sequence Read Archive (SRA), European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) or DDBJ Sequence Read Archive (DRA) identifier linking raw read data, methodological metadata and quality control metrics submitted to the INSDC.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted "run". NCBI-SRA accessions start with SRR, EBI-ENA runs start with ERR and DRA accessions start with DRR.

column16: The GenBank/ENA/DDBJ identifier assigned to the sequence in the INSDC archives.
column17: Store the accession returned from a GenBank/ENA/DDBJ submission.

column16: Metrics regarding the prevalence of the pathogen of interest obtained from a surveillance project.
column17: Risk assessment requires detailed information regarding the quantities of a pathogen in a specified location, commodity, or environment. As such, it is useful for risk assessors to know what types of information are available through documented methods and results. Provide the metric types that are available in the surveillance project sample plan by selecting them from the pick list. The metrics of interest are " Number of total samples collected", "Number of positive samples", "Average count of hazard organism", "Average count of indicator organism". You do not need to provide the actual values, just indicate that the information is available.
column18: Number of total samples collected, Number of positive samples

column16: The details pertaining to the prevalence metrics from a surveillance project.
column17: If there are details pertaining to samples or organism counts in the sample plan that might be informative, provide details using free text.
column18: Hazard organism counts (i.e. Salmonella) do not distinguish between serovars.

column16: The stage of food production.
column17: Provide the stage of food production as free text.

column16: The category of the experimental intervention applied in the food production system.
column17: In some surveys, a particular intervention in the food supply chain in studied. If there was an intervention specified in the sample plan, select the intervention category from the pick list provided.

column16: The details of the experimental intervention applied in the food production system.
column17: If an experimental intervention was applied in the survey, provide details in this field as free text.

column16: The name of the organization that performed the antimicrobial resistance testing.
column17: Provide the name of the agency, organization or institution that performed the AMR testing, in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name of the lab within the organization that performed the antimicrobial resistance testing.
column17: Provide the name of the specific laboratory that performed the AMR testing (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name of the individual or the individual's role in the organization that performed the antimicrobial resistance testing.
column17: Provide the name of an individual or their job title. As personnel turnover may render the contact's name obsolete, it is more preferable to provide a job title for ensuring accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email of the individual or the individual's role in the organization that performed the antimicrobial resistance testing.
column17: Provide the email associated with the listed contact. As personnel turnover may render an individual's email obsolete, it is more preferable to provide an address for a position or lab, to ensure accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The date the antimicrobial resistance testing was performed.
column17: Provide the date according to the ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY".

column16: Names of individuals contributing to the processes of sample collection, sequence generation, analysis, and data submission.
column17: Include the first and last names of all individuals that should be attributed, separated by a comma.
column18: Tejinder Singh, Fei Hu, Joe Blogs

column16: The DataHarmonizer software and template version provenance.
column17: The current software and template version information will be automatically generated in this field after the user utilizes the "validate" function. This information will be generated regardless as to whether the row is valid of not.

column16: An alternative isolate_ID assigned to the isolate by another organization.
column17:
Alternative isolate IDs should be provided in the in a prescribed format which consists of the ID followed by square brackets (no space in between the ID and bracket) containing the short form of ID provider’s agency name i.e. ID[short organization code]. Agency short forms include the following:
Public Health Agency of Canada: PHAC
Canadian Food Inspection Agency: CFIA
Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada: AAFC
Fisheries and Oceans Canada: DFO
Environment and Climate Change Canada: ECCC
Health Canada: HC 
An example of a properly formatted alternative_isolate_identifier would be e.g. XYZ4567[CFIA]
Multiple alternative isolate IDs can be provided, separated by semi-colons.

column16: The identifier assigned to a progenitor isolate derived from an isolate that was directly obtained from a sample.
column17: If your sequence data pertains to progeny of an original isolate, provide the progeny_isolate_ID.

column16: The identifier of the isolate in the IRIDA platform.
column17: Provide the "sample ID" used to track information linked to the isolate in IRIDA. IRIDA sample IDs should be unqiue to avoid ID clash. This is very important in large Projects, especially when samples are shared from different organizations. Download the IRIDA sample ID and add it to the sample data in your spreadsheet as part of good data management practices.

column16: The identifier of the Project in the iRIDA platform.
column17: Provide the IRIDA "project ID".

column16: The name of the agency, organization or institution with which the individual who performed the isolation procedure is affiliated.
column17: Provide the name of the agency, organization or institution that isolated the original isolate in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The specific laboratory affiliation of the individual who performed the isolation procedure.
column17: Provide the name of the specific laboratory that that isolated the original isolate (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name or title of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the isolate.
column17: Provide the name of an individual or their job title. As personnel turnover may render the contact's name obsolete, it is prefereable to provide a job title for ensuring accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the isolate.
column17: Provide the email associated with the listed contact. As personnel turnover may render an individual's email obsolete, it is more prefereable to provide an address for a position or lab, to ensure accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The date on which the isolate was isolated from a sample.
column17: Provide the date according to the ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY".

column16: The date on which the isolate was received by the laboratory.
column17: Provide the date according to the ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY".

column16: The user-defined name for the sample.
column17: The sample_ID should represent the identifier assigned to the sample at time of collection, for which all the descriptive information applies. If the original sample_ID is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The drug which the pathogen was exposed to.
column17: Select a drug from the pick list provided.

column16: The antimicrobial resistance phenotype, as determined by the antibiotic susceptibility measurement and testing standard for this antibiotic
column17: Select a phenotype from the pick list provided.

column16: The measured value of amikacin resistance.
column17: This field should only contain a number (either an integer or a number with decimals).

column16: The units of the antimicrobial resistance measurement.
column17: Select the units from the pick list provided. Use the Term Request System to request the addition of other units if necessary.

column16: The qualifier associated with the antimicrobial resistance measurement
column17: Select the comparator sign from the pick list provided. Use the Term Request System to request the addition of other signs if necessary.

column16: The general method used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing.
column17: Select a typing method from the pick list provided. Use the Term Request System to request the addition of other methods if necessary.

column16: The brand/platform used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing.
column17: Select a typing platform from the pick list provided. Use the Term Request System to request the addition of other platforms if necessary.

column16: The specific name and version of the plate, panel, or other platform used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing.
column17: Include any additional information about the antimicrobial susceptibility test such as the drug panel details.

column16: The name of the vendor of the testing platform used.
column17: Provide the full name of the company (avoid abbreviations).

column16: The testing standard used for determination of resistance phenotype
column17: Select a testing standard from the pick list provided.

column16: The version number associated with the testing standard used for determination of antimicrobial resistance phenotype. If applicable, include a version number for the testing standard used.
column17: If applicable, include a version number for the testing standard used.

column16: Additional details associated with the testing standard used for determination of antimicrobial resistance phenotype
column17: This information may include the year or location where the testing standard was published. If not applicable, leave blank.
column18: 27th ed. Wayne, PA: Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute; 2017.

column16: The maximum measurement, in the units specified in the “antibiotic_measurement_units” field, for a sample to be considered “sensitive” to this antimicrobial.
column17: This field should only contain a number (either an integer or a number with decimals), since the “<=” qualifier is implied.

column16: The intermediate measurement(s), in the units specified in the “AMR_measurement_units” field, where a sample would be considered to have an “intermediate” phenotype for this antimicrobial.
The minimum measurement, in the units specified in the “antibiotic_measurement_units” field, for a sample to be considered “resistant” to this antimicrobial.
column17: This field should only contain a number (either an integer or a number with decimals), since the “>=” qualifier is implied.
